name: Harold Moody
description: Harold Moody was a Jamaican doctor and founder of the LCP whose family home was located here. Harold Moody arrived in Britain from Jamaica in 1904 and trained as a doctor at King's College. His house in Peckham became a central meeting point for a huge number of Caribbean and African political activists and was the initial headquarters for the League of Coloured Peoples (LCP).

description: Coleridge Goode was a Jamaican jazz musician who played at the ballroom here in the mid 1940s.

description: Lauderic Caton was a Trinidadian acefrettist who played at the ballroom here in the mid 1940s.

name: Cecil Belfield Clarke
description: Cecil Belfield Clarke was a Barbadian doctor and LCP member who had a medical practice here.

name: Ray Ellington
description: Ray Ellington was an English singer, drummer and bandleader who played here in the mid 1940s. Ellington fronted the group, now known as the "Ray Ellington Quartet".

name: Lena Horne
description: Lena Horne was an American singer, dancer, actress and activist who visited WASU headquarters in 1947, donating money there.

name: Cecil Belfield Clarke
description: Cecil Belfield Clarke was a Barbadian doctor and LCP member who lived here.

name: Pat Walter
description: Pat Walter was the secretary and partner of Dr Cecil Belfield Clarke.

name: Irene Wellesley Cole
description: Irene Wellesley Cole was the younger sister of Sierra Leonian surgeon Robert Wellesley Cole, who was among those who stayed at Harold Moody's home in Peckham in the early 1940s

name: T.  Ras Makonnen

name: Opeolu ('Olu) Obisanya (Solanke)

name: Ibidun Doherty
description: Ibidun Doherty was a woman who was involved in the WASU hostel's social committee and helped organize dances and music performances

name: Victoria Omolara Bucknor
description: Victoria Omolara Bucknor was a Nigerian woman who was involved in the WASU hostel's social committee and helped organize dances and music performances

name: Irene Howe
description: Irene Howe was a woman who was involved in the WASU hostel's social committee and helped organize dances and music performances

name: G. Nigretti

name: Princess Remi Ademola
description: Remi Ademola was a Nigerian Princess who was honourary treasurer of the WASU hostel and helped organize dances and music performances

name: Learie Constantine
description: Learie Constantine was a famous and accomplished Trinidadian cricketer who attended the first social at the WASU hostel in September 1935

name: Norma Constantine
description: Norma Constantine was a Trinidadian woman who attended the first social at the WASU hostel in September 1935.

name: Hugh O. Beresford Wooding

name: Tinuade Adefolu

name: Adenrele Ademola

name: Titilola Folarin
description: Titilola Folarin was a Nigerian woman who worked for the WASU as Tresurer and was also on its social committee in the second half of the 1930s

name: Jomo Kenyatta
description: Jomo Kenyatta was a Kenyan student and activist and the future president of an independent Kenya who stayed at Aggrey House in the second half of the 1930s. A Colonial Office official patronisingly wrote he had seen him there 'meek and mild and very happy'

name: Opeolu ('Olu) Obisanya (Solanke)
description: Opeolu ('Olu) Obisanya was a Nigerian who worked at Africa House in the late 1930s, helping run the restaurant which served African cuisine

name: Eslanda Robeson
description: Eslanda Robeson was an American anthropologist, author, actor and civil rights activist who visited the WASU hostel in 1935 and 1936

name: Paul Robeson
description: Paul Robeson was an American singer actor and socialist who visited the WASU hostel in 1935 and 1936

name: Fela Sowande
description: Fela Sowande was a Nigerian pianist who was often at the WASU hostel in Camden and helped run musical events there.

name: Joe Kwesi Biney
description: Joe Kwesi Biney was a Ghanaian musician who played at the WASU in 1935 in a ceremony to honour the Robesons

name: John Carter
st_first: The Honourable Society of the Middle Temple
description: John Carter was a Guyanese law student who read law at the Middle Temple, qualifying as a barrister in 1942.

name: Rudolph Dunbar
description: Rudolph Dunbar was a Guyanese clarinetist and bandleader who conducted the London Philharmonic here in 1942. Dunbar attracted an audience of 7,000.

name: Rudolph Dunbar
description: Rudolph Dunbar was a Guyanese clarinetist and bandleader who reported on the Commons debates here following the Italian invasion of Ethiopia. Dunbar was reporting for the "Associated Negro Press".

name: Nathaniel Fadipe
description: Nathaniel Fadipe was a Nigerian writer who studied for his PhD at LSE in the mid-1930s. Fedipe's PhD examined the Yoruba Tribe.

name: John W. Bubbles (Sublett)
description: John W. Bubbles (Sublett) was an American vaudeville performer who appeared on the first regular TV broadcast from this location in November 1936 as one half of the act "Buck and Bubbles".

name: Ford Lee "Buck" Washington
description: Ford Lee "Buck" Washington was an American vaudeville performer who appeared on the first regular TV broadcast from this location in November 1936 as one half of the act "Buck and Bubbles".

name: Adelaide Hall
description: Adelaide Hall was an American jazz singer and entertainer who appeared in "The Sun Never Sets" here in 1938. Hall was feted by the crowds- to the extent that she would settle to live in the UK for the rest of her life.

name: Teddy Hill
description: Teddy Hill was an American big band leader who led the Cotton Club Revue during a London visit in 1937.

name: Dickie Wells
description: Dickie Wells was an American jazz trombonist who perfomed with the Cotton Club here in 1937.

name: Dizzy Gillespie
description: Dizzy Gillespie was an American jazz trumpeter who performed with the Cotton Club here in 1937.

name: W. Arthur Lewis
description: Arthur Lewis was a St Lucian economist who studied for his bachelor's and doctorate here, before becoming Britain's first black lecturer. Lewis, an economic genius, stayed at LSE before taking up a position in Manchester following the end of the war. He would later work for a number of newly-independent developing countries.

name: Workneh Eshete (Charles Martin)
description: Workneh Eshete (Charles Martin) was an Ethiopian doctor and diplomat who was made minister to London "Ethiopian Minister to the court of St James" following the Italian invasion in 1935.

name: R.P. Zaphiro
st_first: Anti Air War Memorial, Highbeam House
description: R.P. Zaphiro was the Secretary of the Imperial Ethiopian Legation who unveiled a monument against air warfare here in October 1935, following the invasion of Ethiopia by Italy.

name: Fela Sowande
description: Fela Sowande was a Nigerian pianist who was music advisor to the Colonial Film Unit here from 1941 onwards.

name: T.  Ras Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who attended a rally for Ethiopia here in 1935. Makonnen found out about the rally by reading an evening paper.

name: T.  Ras Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who took tea here following the rally for Ethiopia in 1935.

name: T.  Ras Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who greated the Ethiopian Emperor here in 1936.

name: Christopher Braithwaite (Jones)
description: Christopher Braithwaite, who sometimes used the surname Jones, was originally from Barbados and after settling in London was part of the party greeting the Ethiopian Emperor here in 1936.

name: Pamela Braithwaite
description: Pamela Braithwaite was the daughter of Chris, who presented flowers to the Ethiopian Emperor following his arrival here in 1936. Makonnen described Pamela as being "dressed up fine"

name: Princess Tsehai
description: Princess Tsehai was the Princess of Ethiopia, who led the Ethiopian delegation that arrived at Waterloo Station.

name: Emperor Haile Selassie
description: Haile Selassie was the exiled Emperor of Ethiopia who arrived here following a train journey from Plymouth in 1936.

name: T.  Ras Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who studied Ethiopian history here following the Italian invasion in 1935.

name: Bresiando
description: Bresiando was a Ghanaian man who was "projecting himself as the leader of an independent African orthodox church" who rented a building next to the Sketch- and who rented out the basement to Makonnen and Padmore. Besiando was in London to earn concessions for Ghanaian cocoa farmers.

name: T.  Ras Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who founded the IASB here in 1937. Makonnen did all of the cleaning in the flat by himself.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who founded the IASB here in 1937.

name: Ato Emmanuel Abraham
description: Ato Emmanuel Abraham was the first secretary of the Ethiopian legation and close friend of Makonnen. Abraham struggled to return to Ethiopia for many years, finally being granted permission to do so in 1943.

name: Ato Emmanuel Abraham
description: First secretary of the Ethiopian legation and close friend of Makonnen. At one point, Abraham was round Makonnen's house "every day".

name: T.  Ras Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who sold copies of "Life and Struggles of Negro Toilers" here in the late 1930s.

name: T.  Ras Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who sold copies of "Life and Struggles of Negro Toilers" here in the late 1930s.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who sold copies of "Life and Struggles of Negro Toilers" here in the late 1930s and attended the rally in support of the Nigerian general strike held here in July 1945.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who attended a National Peace Council meeting here in October 1935. Padmore rebuked the conference from the floor, calling for more African involvement. He went on to sell copies of "Life and Struggles of Negro Toilers" here in the late 1930s.

name: Yakub Osman
description: Yakub Osman was a Sudanese student and future ambassador to the Soviet Union who "literally lived" in Hyde Park at speaker's corner.

name: Taezaz
description: Taezaz was a friend of Makonnen's at the Ethiopian legation who helps to arrange his call for Americans to adopt Ethiopian children.

name: Teklehiwot / Tekle Hawariat
description: Teklehiwot / Tekle Hawariat was a friend of T. Ras Makonnen's at the Ethiopian legation who helps to arrange his call for Americans to adopt Ethiopian children.

name: T.  Ras Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who appealed here for Japanese ships to transport Ethiopian refugees to the US. Makonnen's appeals fell on deaf ears.

name: Edmundo Ros
description: Edmundo Ros was a Trinidadian vocalist and bandleader who studied here between 1937 and 1942.

name: Edmundo Ros
description: Edmundo Ros was a Trinidadian vocalist and bandleader who played in Marino Barreto's band here in 1938.

name: Una Marson
description: Una Marson was a Jamaican journalist and media producer who was among the crowds waiting to greet Haile Selassie on his arrival at Waterloo in 1936.

name: Amy Ashwood Garvey
description: Amy Ashwood Garvey was an activist, business owner and the first wife of Marcus Garvey, who addressed several rallies in Trafalgar Square to protest the Italian invasion of Ethiopia. On one occasion in August 1935 you said: "You have talked of 'The White Man's Burden'...now we are...standing between you and fascism'.

name: Jomo Kenyatta
description: Jomo Kenyatta was a Kenyan student and activist and the future president of an independent Kenya who addressed several rallies in Trafalgar Square to protest the Italian invasion of Ethiopia.

name: Edmundo Ros
description: Edmundo Ros was a Trinidadian vocalist and bandleader who played in Marino Barreto's band here in 1938.

name: Joe Deniz
description: Joe Deniz was a British guitarrist who played here in the 1944 Jazz Jamboree

name: Clara Deniz
description: Clara Deniz was a black British pianist and the wife of Frank Deniz who played here in the 1944 Jazz Jamboree, alonside American big band leader Glenn Miller.

name: Frank Deniz
description: Frank Deniz was a British guitarrist and husband of Clara Deniz who played here in 1944 Jazz Jamboree, alongside American big band leader Glenn Miller.

name: H.O. Davies
description: Olagunju Davies was a Nigerian student in London who also reported on the arrival of Haile Selassie in London for the Nigerian Daily Times

name: Joseph Martin
description: Joseph Martin was the Ethiopian Legate's son who was educated in the UK, and present at rallies against the Italian invasion in Trafalgar Square before being executed on his return to the country in 1937

name: Benjamin Martin
description: Benjamin Martin was the Ethiopian Legate's son who was educated in the UK, and present at rallies against the Italian invasion in Trafalgar Square before being executed on his return to the country in 1937.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who became reacquainted with childhood friend C.L.R. James at a meeting of the League Against Imperialism here.

name: C.L.R. James
description: C.L.R. James was a Trinidadian historian and activist who became reacquainted here with childhood friend George Padmore at a meeting of the League Against Imperialism.

name: Peter Blackman
description: Peter Blackman was a Marxist scholar, poet and chair of the Negro Welfare Association who spoke to a crowd of 10,000 at a rally here.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who was here as it was the temporary meeting place for activists associated with the IAFE who eventually formed the PAF.

name: Jomo Kenyatta
description: Jomo Kenyatta was a Kenyan student and activist and the future president of an independent Kenya who met other IAFE activists here.

description: Robert Broadhurst was a founding member of the Pan-African Federation which began here in 1936

description: George E. Moore was a Ghanaian man and founding member of the Pan-African Federation which began here in 1936

name: J.J. Magade
description: J.J. Magade was a South African man and founding member of the Pan-African Federation which began here in 1936

name: Richie Riley
description: Richie Riley was a Jamaican classically trained dancer and old friend of Berto Pasuka who helped to establish Les Ballets Negres.

name: Ivor Cummings
description: Ivor Cummings was the British son of a Sierra Leonese physician who was Warden of Aggrey House in 1935. Cummings reported to the Colonial Office that two young men had snuck off to the WASU to spend time with two girls

name: Amy Ashwood Garvey
description: Amy Ashwood Garvey was an activist, business owner and the first wife of Marcus Garvey, who administered the "Ethiopian Defence Fund" here from October 1935, and was a vice president of the IASB.

name: Louis Mbanefo
description: Louis Mbanefo was a Nigerian law student in London who was a member of the WASU and the LCP. He moved to Cambridge in 1936 to obtain a humanities degree.

name: Desmond Buckle
description: Desmond Buckle was a Ghanaian activist and the first African member of the CPGB who was Secretary and then President of the Gold Coast Students Association during its time in Aggrey House.

name: Desmond Buckle
description: Desmond Buckle was a Ghanaian activist and the first African member of the CPGB who attended the "Conference on African Peoples, Democracy and World Peace" here in July 1939.

name: Peter Blackman
description: Peter Blackman was a Barbadian Marxist scholar, poet and chair of the Negro Welfare Association who attended the "Conference on African Peoples, Democracy and World Peace" here in July 1939.

name: Princess Tsehai
description: Princess Tsehai was the Princess of Ethiopia, who attended the "Conference on African Peoples, Democracy and World Peace" here in July 1939.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who attended the "Conference on African Peoples, Democracy and World Peace" here in July 1939.

name: Harold Moody
description: Harold Moody was a Jamaican doctor and founder of the LCP who attended the "Conference on African Peoples, Democracy and World Peace" here in July 1939.

name: Robert Gardiner
description: Robert Gardiner was a Ghanaian economist who established a fortnightly study group here in 1941. The study group aimed to keep the students informed of the latest economic, political and cultural developments in West Africa, through the presentation of researched discussion papers.

name: Bankole Awoonor-Renner
description: Bankole Awoonor-Renner was a Ghanaian journalist and commited communist who gives a speech here in August 1943. Awoonor-Renner's powerful speech demand[ed] freedom for West Africa and denounc[ed] indirect rule, and reminded the delegation of the racial discrimination that was still practiced in Britain.

name: H.O. Davies
description: Olagunju Davies was a Nigerian student in London who was secretary-general of WASU in 1945, having previously been President in the mid-1930s. Davies was unpopular amoungst Igbo members of the WASU and in March 1945 a general meeting established a commission of enquiry to investigate allegations made against him.

name: Nnamdi Azikiwe
description: Nnamdi "Zik" Azikiwe was the future president of Nigeria, who stayed in the second Africa House during a visit in 1943.

name: Obafemi Awolowo
description: Obafemi Awolowo was a Nigerian statesman who was involved with the WASU in the mid-1940s. Awolowo increased the focus of the WASU on Nigerian affairs, leading to an exodus of Ghanaian students.

name: T.A. Bankole
description: T.A.Bankole was the President of the Nigerian Trade Union Confederation, who attented the World Trade Union Conference here in 1945. Bankole mantained a close level of contact with the PAF and the WASU whilst in London.

name: T.A. Bankole
description: T.A.Bankole was the President of the Nigerian Trade Union Confederation, who attented a meeting of the West African Parliamentary Committee here in 1945.

name: Roland W. Beoku-Betts
description: Roland W. Beoku-Betts was the Sierra Leonese WASU President in 1945 who chaired a rally in support of the Nigerian general strike here in July of that year.

name: Egbert Udo Udoma
description: Egbert Udo Udoma was a Nigerian law student who addressed the rally held here in 1945 support of the Nigerian general strike.

name: H.O. Davies
description: Olagunju Davies was a Nigerian student in London who, as Secretary-general of WASU, addressed the rally held here in 1945 support of the Nigerian general strike.

name: Adeyemo Alakija
description: Adeyemo Alakija was a Nigerian lawyer who was knighted here in 1945.

name: Abe Desmore
description: Abe Desmore was a South African activist who spoke at a meeting of the LCP in January 1935.

name: Ras T. Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who lived here.

name: Seretse Khama
description: Seretse Khama was the first president of Botswana who briefly lived here with Moody in 1945.

name: William Harrison
description: William Harrison was an African American who lived here.

name: Alfred B. Xuma
st_first: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine
description: Alfred B. Xuma was a South African leader, activist and president-general of the African National Congress (ANC) from 1940 to 1949 who studied here in the late 1930s. Xuma made contact with people representing a wide range of pan-Africanist political sentiment, including George Padmore and other members of the IASB.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who led meetings of the IASB at its headquarters here.

name: C.L.R. James
description: CLR James was a Trinidadian historian and activist who was a leading figure involved in meetings of the IASB at its headquarters.

description: Amy Ashwood Garvey was an activist, business owner and the first wife of Marcus Garvey, who was a co-vice chair involved in meetings of the IASB at its headquarters

name: Jomo Kenyatta
description: Jomo Kenyatta was a Kenyan student and activist and the future president of an independent Kenya who was a co-vice chair involved in meetings of the IASB at its headquarters

name: Robert Broadhurst
description: Robert Broadhurst was a founding member of the Pan-African Federation who was treasurer of the IASB and involved in meetings at its headquarters

name: T.  Ras Makonnen
description: T. Ras Makonnen was a Guyanese activist and founder of the pan-African federation, who involved in meetings at IASB headquarters here.

name: Aida Bastian
description: Aida Bastian was a Jamaican man on the executive committee of the IASB and attended meetings at its headquarters

name: Adetokunbo Adegboyega Ademola
description: Adetokunbo Adegboyega Ademola was a Nigerian man involved in WASU and attended meetings of the IASB at its headquarters

name: Laminah Sankoh
description: Laminah Sankoh was a Sierra Leonese man involved in WASU and attended meetings of the IASB at its headquarters

name: Arnold Ward
description: Arnold Ward was a Barbabadian former communist who joined the IASB and attended meetings at its headquarters after his expulsion from the Communist Party

name: Constance Horton (Cummings-John)
description: Constance Horton (Cummings-John) was a woman from Sierra Leone who joined the IASB and attended meetings at its headquarters

name: Sam Manning
description: Sam Manning was a Trinidadian calypso singer and joint owner/ founder of Florence Mills Social Parlour who attended early meetings of the IASB

name: Lawrence Brown
description: Lawrence Brown was an American man who attended early meetings of the IASB

name: Peter Milliard
description: Peter Milliard was a Guyanese man who 'participated in its [the IASB's] activities'

name: James Headley
description: James Headley was a man who 'participated in its [the IASB's] activities'

name: Babalola Wilkie
description: Babalola Wilkie was a Nigerian man who 'participated in its [the IASB's] activities'

name: Desmond Buckle
description: Desmond Buckle was a Ghanaian activist and the first African member of the CPGB, headquartered at this location. Buckle was also regularly attended CPGB conferences.

name: Ralph Bunche
description: Ralph Bunche was a future US diplomat and nobel prize winner who visited Harold Moody here in 1937. Bunche described Moody disparagingly afterwards.

name: Aduke Alakija
description: Aduke Alakija was the first female President of the WASU who studied for a social science degree here.

name: Aduke Alakija
description: Aduke Alakija was the first female President of the WASU in 1945.

name: H.O. Davies
description: Olagunju Davies was a Nigerian student in London who was President of the WASU in 1935.

name: H.O. Davies
description: Olagunju Davies was a Nigerian student in London who was President of the Cosmopolitan Club at LSE at the same time as he held the Presidency of the WASU in 1935.

name: George Brown
description: George Brown was an American economic historian who studied at LSE in 1935. Brown was friends with Davies and Arthur Lewis

name: George Brown
description: George Brown was an American economic historian who served as publicity secretary in the LCP in 1935. At the end of 1935, Brown departed for Liberia.

name: W. Arthur Lewis
description: Arthur Lewis was a St Lucian economist who played an active role in the LCP throughout the 1930s.

name: H.O. Davies
description: Olagunju Davies was a Nigerian student in London who served in the executive committee of the LCP in 1936-7.

name: Lorenzo Turner
ad_hist: School of Oriental and African Studies
description: Lorenzo Turner was an African American linguist who researcheed African language systems at SOAS in 1937.

name: Jomo Kenyatta
ad_hist: School of Oriental and African Studies
description: Jomo Kenyatta was a Kenyan student and activist and the future president of an independent Kenya who occasionally worked as a translator for Ida Ward at SOAS.

name: Paul Robeson
ad_hist: School of Oriental and African Studies
description: Paul Robeson was an American singer actor and socialist who studies African linguistics here in the mid-1930s.

name: Peter Mbiyu Koinage
description: Peter Mbiyu Koinage was a student from Kenya who began an advanced degree in anthropology here but didn't complete it.

name: Joseph William de Graft Johnson
description: Joseph William de Graft Johnson was a Ghanaian educationalist who studied here in 1937. Bunche and Kenyatta didn't like de Graft, the former calling him a "typical Uncle Tom".

name: Prince Cobina Kessie
description: Prince Cobina Kessie was an Ashanti Prince and former editor of WASU who studied here in 1937.

name: Don M'Timkulu
description: Don M'Timkulu was a Zulu anthropologist who studied here in 1937.

name: Nathaniel Fadipe
description: Nathaniel Fadipe was a Nigerian writer who worked as a Yoruba-translator for the Ministry of Information here. Fedipe also worked as a private Yoruba tutor.

name: Nathaniel Fadipe
description: Nathaniel Fadipe was a Nigerian writer who worked as a clerk for the Unilever Corporation following the completion of his PhD. Fedipe died in 1944.

name: Elsa V. Goveia
description: Elsa V. Goveia was a Guyanese historian who won the British Guiana scholarship to study at UCL in 1944, going on to complete her PhD here in 1950. Goveia was the first woman to win the coveted scholarship.

name: Prince Akiki Nyabongo
description: Prince Akiki Nyabongo was a writer and Ugandan prince who studied at LSE in 1937. Nyabongo was part of the "Africa Group" who Ralph Bunche often spent time with.

name: Ebenezer Ako-Adjei
description: Ebenezer Ako-Adjei was the future minister for External Affairs in Ghana and one-time President of WASU who was an active member of the WASU study group in the mid-1940s. Ako-Adjei returned to the Gold Coast in 1947.

name: Lucille Walrond (Mathurn Mair)
description: Lucille Walrond (Mathurn Mair) was a Jamaican studying English history at UCL. Walrond, now Mair, would later study her PhD at the University of the West Indies under Elsa V. Goveia.

name: Lucille Walrond (Mathurn Mair)
description: Lucille Walrond (Mathurn Mair) was a Jamaican student of English history who socialized with Elsa Goveia at WISU meetings here. Walrond, now Mair, would later study her PhD at the University of the West Indies under Goveia.

name: Elsa V. Goveia
description: Elsa V. Goveia was a Guyanese historian who socialized with Lucille Walrond at WISU meetings here.

name: Max Yergan
description: Max Yergan was a South African activist who met Ralph Bunche at a visit to Paul Robeson here in 1937. The visit laid the grounwork for the tea party at the Bunche's two days later.

name: Ralph Bunche
description: Ralph Bunche was a future US diplomat and nobel prize winner who visited Paul Robeson here in 1937, where he met American activist Max Yergan. The visit laid the grounwork for the tea party at the Bunche's two days later.

name: Robert Adams
description: Robert Adams was a Guyanese actor who was barred from performing at the National Gallery during the filming of "Men of Two Worlds" becuase he was black.

name: Rudolph Dunbar
description: Rudolph Dunbar was a Guyanese clarinetist and bandleader who worked as a press officer for the Ministry of Information during the Second World War.

name: Fela Sowande
description: Fela Sowande was a Nigerian pianist who became a fellow at the Royal College of Organists here in 1943. Sowande headed his class and garnered a litany of prizes and awards.

name: Eric Williams
description: Eric Williams was a Trinidadian student, historian and future Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago was visited George Padmore's flat here on Cranleigh Street.

name: Robert Adams
description: Robert Adams was a Guyanan actor who pelayed the protagonist in "Colony" here in 1939 and joins the Theatre's professional company in 1946. Adams played the main role due to Robeson's recent return to the United States.

name: Ladipo Solanke
description: Ladipo Solanke was a Nigerian student, lawyer and the co-founder of the West African Student's Union who met here weekly as part of the West Africa Parliamentary Committee.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who ran the IASB out of this office on St Bride Street after 1939.

name: R.W. Beoku-Betts
description: R.W. Beoku-Betts WASU President in 1945 who attended weekly meetings of the West Africa Parliamentary Committee here.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who reported on House of Commons discussions about labour unrest in the Caribbean for the Chicago Defender.

name: Robert Gardiner
description: Robert Gardiner was a Ghanain economist who attented weekly meetings of the West Africa Parliamentary Committee here.

name: F.O. Blaize
description: F.O. Blaize was a wealthy Nigerian merchant who attends weekly meetings of the West Africa Parliamentary Committee here.

name: I. T. A. Wallace-Johnson
description: I. T. A. Wallace-Johnson was a Sierra Leonese activist who attended the World Federation of Trade Unions here in 1945.

name: Arthur Lewis
description: Arthur Lewis was a St Lucian economist who spoke at a meeting organized by the LCP to protest British actions in the Caribbean during a wave of strikes and civil unrest in 1938

name: Harold Moody
description: Harold Moody was a Jamaican doctor and founder of the LCP who was part of a delegation that went to the Colonial Office to protest British actions in the Caribbean during a waves of strikes and civil unrest in 1938.

name: Kwame Nkrumah
description: Kwame Nkrumah was an African activist and the future president of an independent Ghana who arrived here in 1945. Nkrumah met Appiah and Padmore at the station.

name: Nana Joseph Emmanuel Appiah
description: Nana Joseph Emmanuel Appiah was a Ghanaian radical who met Nkrumah here in 1945. Appiah proceeded to a railway union meeting, where he was speaking.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who met Nkrumah here in 1945.

name: Titilola Folarin
description: Titilola Folarin was a Nigerian woman who recounted that shops in Regent Street started to sell 'ladies' hats, almost in exactly the same style and shape' as she and her associates had worn when shopping there on previous occassions

name: Johnny Smythe
description: Johnny Smythe was a Sierra Leonese pilot who worked for the Colonial Office following the end of the Second World War. Smythe's job was to "help Commonwealth servicemen"

name: Ethnan Cummings-John
description: Ethnan Cummings-John was the warden of Aggrey House, a barrister who was also a member of the LCP. He was present at an "Informal Conference" held at Friend's House in February 1937. The conference was aimed at settling disputes between Aggrey House and WASU.

name: Irene Wellesley Cole
description: Irene Wellesley Cole was the younger sister of Sierra Leonian surgeon Robert Wellesley Cole, who joined the WASU during the 1940s while studying medicine in London and addressed its 1942 conference, and was also active in the LCP

name: Una Marson
description: Una Marson was a Jamaican journalist and media producer who attended a talk at the Royal Empire Society where she reported disapprovingly that 'I gathered from the speech by the white Rhodesian that African women did not exist in Rhodesia'.

name: Lloyd Braithwaite
description: Lloyd Braithwaite was a Trinidadian sociologist who stayed at the student accomodation here whilst studying at LSE in the mid-1940s.

name: Lloyd Braithwaite
description: Lloyd Braithwaite was a Trinidadian sociologist who studied at LSE in the mid-1940s

name: Reg Phillips
description: Reg Phillips was a Jamaican who studied for the two-year Social Science Administration course at LSE in the mid-1940s.

name: Winnie Birkbeck-Hewitt
description: Winnie Birkbeck-Hewitt was a Jamaican who studied for the two-year Social Science Administration course at LSE in the mid-1940s.

name: Ivor Robinson
description: Ivor Robinson was a Guyanan who studied for the two-year Social Science Administration course at LSE in the mid-1940s.

name: Ken Sealy
description: Ken Sealy was a Trinidadian who studied for the two-year Social Science Administration course at LSE in the mid-1940s.

name: Gladstone E. Mills
description: Gladstone E. Mills was a Jamaican who studied for the two-year Social Science Administration course at LSE in the mid-1940s.

name: Gladstone E. Mills
description: Gladstone E. Mills was a Jamaican who stayed at the student accomodation here whilst studying at LSE in the mid-1940s.

name: Abubakar Tafawa Balewa
description: Abubakar Tafawa Balewa was the first Prime Minister of independent Nigeria who stayed at the student accomodation here in the mid-1940s.

name: Una Marson
description: Una Marson was a Jamaican journalist and media producer who had a small temporary office at Bedford College in Regent's Park before it was hit by a bomb.

name: Forbes Burnham
description: Forbes Burnham was the future Prime Minister and President of Guyana who stayed in the student accomodation here whilst studying at LSE in the mid 1940s.

name: Ethel Marson
description: Ethel Marson was a Jamaican civil servant who was staying with her sister, Una, at her Hampstead flat at the time of the 1939 Register

name: Maida Springer
description: Maida Springer was an American trade unionist, originally from Panama, who travelled from Harlem to London to attended many social and intellectual gathering at Una Marson's flat, recalling there was 'very explosive talk!'

name: Milton Cato
description: Milton Cato was the future Prime Minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines who stayed in the student accomodation in the mid 1940s. Cato had just been honourably discharged from the Canadian armed forces, with whom he had fought in the Second World War.

name: Charles Njonjo
description: Charles Njonjo was the future Attorney-General of Kenya who stayed here at some point.

name: N I Ejindu
description: N I Ejindu was a Nigerian trainee-teacher shown teaching a group of white children here in 1946.

name: C.L.R. James
description: C.L.R. James was a Trinidadian historian and activist who participated in a WASU debate here in 1936. The debate took up the question of â€œgreater cooperation between Africans and West Indiansâ€. Africans criticized Caribbeans for imitating whites and for â€œtheir ignorance of the cultures of their forefathers". The debate was hailed as a sign of change. Participants agreed that Caribbeans needed to discard â€œthe anti- African propaganda with which their educational system is saturatedâ€ and to â€œre- establish contact with the civilizations in which they have their roots.â€ James understood the points made that night.

name: C.L.R. James
description: CLR James was a Trinidadian historian and activist who addressed an IAFE rally here in 1935. James informed the crowd that if Ethiopians lost their fight against Italy, â€œwe look to them to destroy their country rather than hand it over to the invader.â€ He added, â€œLet them burn down Addis Ababa, let them poison their wells and water- holes, let them destroy every blade of vegetation.â€

name: Peter Milliard
description: Peter Milliard was a Guyanese man who was vice-chair of the IAFE which met and organized here.

name: Jomo Kenyatta
description: Jomo Kenyatta was a Kenyan student and activist and the future president of an independent Kenya who was honourary secretary of the IAFE which met and organized here.

name: Sam Manning
description: Sam Manning was a Trinidadian calypso singer and joint owner/ founder of Florence Mills Social Parlour who was an executive member of the IAFE which met and organized here.

name: Arnold Ward
description: Arnold Ward was a Barbabadian former communist who addressed the IAFE rally for Ethiopia here in August 1935.

name: Ras Prince Monolulu
description: Ras Prince Monolulu, born Peter Carl Mackay, was a famous racing tipster who attended the Iinternational African Friends of Ethiopia rally here in August 1935, carrying an Ethiopian flag.

name: C.L.R. James
description: C.L.R. James was a Trinidadian historian and activist who addressed an IAFE rally here in August 1935 and an IASB rally in 1938. At the 1935 rally, James said â€œAbyssinia is a backward nationâ€ in need of â€œwestern civilization,â€ though not the barbaric civilization of Italian fascism.

name: Eric Williams
description: Eric Williams was a Trinidadian student, historian and future Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago who regularly attended IAFE speeches here, even appearing on the speakerâ€™s platform.

name: George Padmore
st_first: Oak Cottage, No.27 Burghley Road, Wimbledon
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who visited ILP radical Reginald Reynolds and his wife Ethel Mannin here regularly whilst trying to earn support for the IAFE and the IASB.

name: I. T. A. Wallace-Johnson
description: I. T. A. Wallace-Johnson was a Sierra Leonese activist who found the IASB temporary headquarters here in 1937. Frequently without money for food or even bus fare, Wallce-Johnson was evicted from his flat for failing to pay rent, and he began sleeping in the IASBâ€™s office. Desperate, he also began dipping into the bureauâ€™s meager financial reserves. In April 1938, when the executive committee discovered that Wallace- Johnson was taking money, it expelled him, and he returned to Sierra Leone

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who was chair of the IASB during the time it was headquartered here.

name: Jomo Kenyatta
description: Jomo Kenyatta was a Kenyan student and activist and the future president of an independent Kenya who was vice-chair of the IASB during the time that is headquartered here. With Padmore as chair, Ashwood and Kenyatta as vice chairs, and WallaceJohnson as general secretary, the IASB took as its motto â€œEducate, Co-operate, Emancipate. Neutral in nothing affecting the African people."

name: Amy Ashwood Garvey
description: Amy Ashwood Garvey was an activist, business owner and the first wife of Marcus Garvey, who was vice-chair of the IASB during the time that is headquartered here.

name: Arnold Ward
description: Arnold Ward was a Barbabadian former communist who addressed the the National Peace Council conference here in October 1935. Ward addressed the white liberals, who included Virginia Woolf, and accussed them of being preoccupied with Europe at the expense of Africa.

name: Kenneth Hill
description: Kenneth Hill was a Jamaican trade unionist who attended the WFTU congress here in 1945 where he demanded complete self-determination for all colonial peoples of Africa, the West Indies, and the Pacific area. Hill, representing Caribbean workers, and Wallace-Johnson, representing African workers, were among the delegates appointed to draw up a constitution and a program for the new federation.

name: Henry Lee Moon
description: Henry Lee Moon was an American journalist who covered the WFTU congress here in 1945. First involved with the WFTU through the CIO, he became instrumental in securing black American involvement in the Manchester Pan-African Congress and promoting interest in the event. Besides covering international labor conferences, he familiarized African American audiences with African trade union leaders.

name: Marcus Garvey
description: Marcus Garvey was a black nationalist and activist and the founder of "Garveyism" who spoke here at Speaker's Corner, to dwindling audiences, during his years in London. Garvey's appearances were often mocked by his audience.

name: Harold Moody
description: Harold Moody was a Jamaican doctor and founder of the LCP who joined the management committee of Aggrey House in 1935. Moody's decision to support Aggrey House as soon as it opened led to "bitterness" between the LCP and the WASU and his labelling as an "Uncle Tom".

name: Gilbert Coka
description: Gilbert Coka was a South African who was on the executive committee of the IASB duing the time that it was heaquartered here.

name: Emperor Haile Selassie
description: Haile Selassie was the exiled Emperor of Ethiopia who took place in the "Conference on African Peoples, Democracy and World Peace" here in July 1939. The Conference passed a unanimous decleration condeming any reurn of Germany's African colonies.

name: Ollie Stewart
description: Ollie Stewart was an American reporter who solicited letters from 'American girls' for RAF member Vincent Bunting to be sent to his address here. One night at the House, Stewart awoke to a rat knawing at his chocolate bar. Stewart ate the chocolate, but then lay awake for the rest of the night as the rat scurried arond looking for it.

name: Ollie Stewart
description: Ollie Stewart was an American reporter who worked at the press room in the Ministry of Information and met George Padmore and Rudolph Dunbar while there

name: Ollie Stewart
description: Ollie Stewart was an American reporter who reported meeting Oxford students and flyers from India, Africa and the West Indies while at Aggrey House in September 1942

name: Ollie Stewart
description: Ollie Stewart was an American reporter who reported comments made by Eleanor Roosevelt when she visited the US Embassy in October 1942

name: Elizabeth Phillips
description: Elizabeth Phillips was the first African American women to be sent to report on the war who was hospitalized here for a short period in late 1944 and early 1945

name: Randy Dixon
description: Randy Dixon was a correspondent for the Pittsburgh Courier who visited Elizabeth Phillips while she was in hospital in December 1944

name: Minnie Street
description: Minnie Street, from Louisville Kentucky, was assistant director of a Red Cross unit who was hospitalized with appendicitus here for several months in 1944

name: George Williams
description: George Williams was an American from New York who spent time in his military hospital with a bad stomach before returning to the signal corp unit in France.

name: Milton Shaw
description: Milton Shaw was an American from LA who spent time in this hospital briefly havig arrived in the UK in 1942 as a clerk with a quartermaster unit.

name: Roland Hayes
description: Roland Hayes was a famous African American tenor who performed with a choir of 200 black GIs at an event here in 1943

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who visited here and met Swaraj Freedom House founder K.M.Kumria. Though he was an ardent opponent of nationalism, Padmore was friends with many Indian nationalists, including Nehru.

name: Marcus Garvey
description: Marcus Garvey was a black nationalist and pan-African activist who attended a "mixed-race" meeting here in October 1936. Garvey reported on the meeting for British abolitionist Lady Kathleen Simon.

name: Princess Tsehai
description: Princess Tsehai was the Princess of Ethiopia, who worked at GOSH as a student nurse in the late 1930s. Whilst working here, the Princess became good friends with British abolitionist Lady Kathleen Simon, who "admired" her.

name: Paul Robeson
description: Paul Robeson was an American singer actor and socialist who performed here in 1938 to raise money in support of German refugees. Robeson's performance took place simultaneously to an exhibition on c-20th German art.

name: Harold Moody
description: Harold Moody was a Jamaican doctor and founder of the LCP who tried to create a place where social gatherings and political protest combined by establishing another LCP headquarters here in 1944.

name: Esther Cooper
description: Esther Cooper was an American activist who attended the World Youth Congress here in 1945. Signifying a major event in global decolonisation in the immediate postwar period, the gathering called for the end of Europeam colonial empires.

name: Jomo Kenyatta
description: Jomo Kenyatta was a Kenyan student and activist and the future president of an independent Kenya who visited George Padmore here frequently.

name: Kwame Nkrumah
description: Kwame Nkrumah was an African activist and the future president of an independent Ghana who attended the World Youth Conference here in November 1945. The gathering called for the end of Europeam colonial empires and included scores of delegates from Africa, Asia and the Caribbean.

name: W.E.B. Du Bois
description: W.E.B. Du Bois was an American activist, historian and pan-African who attended the World Youth Conference here in November 1945. Signifying a major event in global decolonisation in the immediate postwar period, the gathering called for the end of Europeam colonial empires.

name: Edmundo Ross
description: Edmundo Ross was a Trinidadian vocalist and bandleader who formed an orchestra that played here during the Second World War. The Coconut Grove allowed employees and their immediate relations shelter during the Blitz- until they discovered that a "corner was flea-ridden, so they had to clear everybody out and clear it up."

name: Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson
description: Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson was a jazz band leader and dancer who lived here with his white partner Gerald Hamilton in 1940. Upon the start of the Blitz, the couple moved out to a cottage in Bray, Berkshire.

name: James Adewale
description: James Adewale was a Nigerian tailor who arrived in London in 1943 to volunteer for the war effort and was sent to Normandy to smuggle goods to the Resistance. He said "On our way back from Normandy we ran into enemy mines and our ship was blown up. Fortunately, I was one of the lucky survivors of that incident."

name: Bildad Kaggia
description: Bildad Kaggia was a Kenyan activist and future religious leader who joined the Kenyan army when the Second World War broke out and was deployed in London as a company quarter-sergeant at a war office meant to rehabilitate African soldiers. During his time there, Kaggia studied political science, journalism and trade unionism through correspondence.

name: Una Marson
description: Una Marson was a Jamaican journalist and media producer who met the Ethiopian minister to London at the Legation here to volunteer for the Ethiopian war effort. The Ethiopians had a colossal amount of work for Marson to do as they did not have a regular typist to handle their correspondence. She was paid very little due to the lack of funds the Ethiopians possessed. Marson also studied the country and lectured on behalf of Ethiopia in England.

name: David Pitt
description: David Pitt was a Grenadian surgeon who opened a medical practice here in 1947. His surgery was a focus for expatriate West Indians.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who frequently spoke here in the late 1930s.

name: C.L.R. James
description: CLR James was a Trinidadian historian and activist who frequently spoke here in the late 1930s. James commented on the oddity of the fact that three West Indians â€“ himself, Padmore and Garvey â€“ should fight out the distant battles of the Caribbean, during the upsurge of rioting, at Speakersâ€™ Corner.

name: Una Marson
description: Una Marson was a Jamaican journalist and media producer who was tutored here by Cecil Madden in the summer of 1939. At that time Alexandra Palace was a site of unpredictable chaos with cables inside all over the floor, some of them as big as water hoses.

name: Desmond Buckle
description: Desmond Buckle was a Ghanaian activist and the first African member of the CPGB who attended the Communist Party of Great Britain conference here in 1947. Buckle linked colonialism to capitalism at the conference, stating that "it would be of no benefit for a colony to acquire nominal independence which left the monopolies intact"

name: Cecil Belfield Clarke
description: Cecil Belfield Clarke was a Barbadian doctor and LCP member who spoke at Aggrey House in 1936 on the topic of venereal disease.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who frequently spoke here in the 1930s.

name: Christine Moody
description: Christine Moody was the eldest daughter of Harold Moody who lived here with her parents and siblings. Christine noted that the number of lodgers in their house constantly fluctuated, but her (white) mother simply "got on" with things.

name: Berto Pasuka
description: Berto Pasuka was a Jamaican choreographer and artistic director of Les Ballets Negres who studied here during the Second World War.

name: George W. Goodman
description: George W. Goodman was the African-American Director of the American Red Cross in London. He wrote that his mission was "to indicate as nearly as possible that color really does not run off and that human impetus comes out of the mind, not the complexion."

name: Christopher Braithwaite (Jones)
description: Christopher Braithwaite, who sometimes used the surname Jones, was originally from Barbados and after settling in London founded the Colonial Seamen's Association here in 1935 as a result of discriminatory legislation. Braithwaite emerged as the foremost leader of black and Asian seamen.

name: Christopher Braithwaite (Jones)
description: Christopher Braithwaite, who sometimes used the surname Jones, was originally from Barbados and after settling in London attended the fifth annual conference of the League of Coloured Peoples here in 1937. Braithwaite said that the majority of black people in Britain were originally seamen, and that it is only through want of work that they had been obliged to remain ashore and took up such jobs as they could obtain. He gave a distressing account of the life they lead, and specially of those who had children to feed.

name: Christopher Braithwaite (Jones)
description: Christopher Braithwaite, who sometimes used the surname Jones, was originally from Barbados and after settling in London founded the Colonial Seamen's Association and spoke on the topic "colonial blacks on the move" here in 1943.

name: Pamela Braithwaite
description: Pamela Braithwaite was the daughter of Chris, who lived here with her dad in some poverty. After his death, a releif effort was organised to look after the children.

name: Jeanette Braithwaite
description: Jeanette Braithwaite was the daughter of Chris, who lived here with her dad in some poverty.

name: Catherine Braithwaite
description: Catherine Braithwaite was the daughter of Chris, who lived here with her dad in some poverty.

name: Sian Braithwaite
description: Sian Braithwaite was the daughter of Chris, who lived here with her dad in some poverty.

name: Laurie Braithwaite
description: Laurie Braithwaite was the son of Chris, who lived here with his dad in some poverty.

name: Reginald Jones Braithwaite
description: Reginald Jones Braithwaite was the son of Chris, who lived here with his dad in some poverty.

name: John Payne
description: John Payne was an African American singer who performed at the LCP's fifth annual garden party at Dr Cecil Belfield Clarke's house in 1936

name: Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson
description: Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson was a jazz band leader and dancer who performed at the LCP's fifth annual garden party at Dr Cecil Belfield Clarke's house in 1936.

name: Amy Ashwood Garvey
description: Amy Ashwood Garvey was an activist, business owner and the first wife of Marcus Garvey, who presided over a meeting of the IAFE here in July 1935

name: C.L.R. James
description: C.L.R. James was a Trinidadian historian and activist who gave a speech on the Ethiopian crises here in July 1935

name: Emmanuel McDonald Bailey
description: Emmanuel McDonald Bailey was a Trinidadian sprinter and RAF volunteer who met his future wife, Doris, 'a bonny Cockney wrac' here in 1942. They subsequently had five children.
citation: (The Guardian, "Oo does 'e think 'e is? Trinidad's sprint sensation still flying", Frank Keating, 2000)

name: Mr Wilkins
description: Mr Wilkins was a West Indian man who was excluded from Aggrey House for "immoral conduct" in 1940. Wilkins had been accused of introducing a â€˜prostitute' into Aggrey House, and hence bringing the institution into disrepute.

name: John Payne
description: John Payne was an African American singer who performed at Aggrey House in June 1936.

name: Elisabeth Welch
description: Elisabeth Welch was an American singer, actress and entertainer who appeared on BBC Television from 1937 onwards, becoming a viewer's favourite.

name: Ollie Stewart
description: Ollie Stewart was an American reporter who saw two "coloured servicemen" after watching a film here in 1942.

name: Elisabeth Welch
description: Elisabeth Welch was an American singer, actress and entertainer who appeared in "happy and glorious" here in the mid-1940s, recieiving 40 per cent of the billing and performing for two hours a night.

name: Alexander B. Mapp
description: Alexander B. Mapp was an American activist who attended the World Youth Conference here in 1945 as a representative of the "Urban League".

name: Sgt. Christopher Lipscombe
description: Sgt. Christopher Lipscombe was a New Jersey GI who won a services track and field championship here in 1945.

name: Sgt. R.T. Barnes
description: Sgt. R.T. Barnes was a Canadian sergeant who visited the American Liberty Club in April 1944, and asked questions to "brain trust" representative J.A.Clark over tea.

name: Whelton Whittle
description: Whelton Whittle was a New York technician who was at the American Liberty Club in April 1944, and asked questions to "brain trust" representative J.A.Clark over tea.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who spoke here to condemn the use of Indian troops in SE Asia.

name: W.E.B. Du Bois
description: W.E.B. Du Bois was an American activist, historian and pan-African who spoke here to condemn the use of Indian troops in SE Asia.

name: C.L.R. James
description: C.L.R. James edited the Trotskeyist publication Fight! which was published here by the Narod Press

name: Grantley Adams
description: Grantley Adams was a Barbadian politician who travelled to London in 1937 and gave a talk here at an event about labour unrest in the Caribbean organized by the LCP

name: Desmond Buckle
description: Desmond Buckle attended a meeting of the LCP here that discussed labour unrest in the Caribbean in August 1938

name: William B. Black
description: William B. Black was an American GI with 643rd Port Company who visited here whilst on leave. He later thought of the torture chamber room whilst crossing the Pacific.

name: William B. Black
description: William B. Black was an American GI with 643rd Port Company who spend Christmas day here in 1944. He loved playing with the British children at the Party, who referred to him as a "chocolate soldier".

name: Cleather H. Hathcock
description: Cleather H. Hathcock was an American corporal from Alachua, Florida who attended the Criminial Investigation Department (CID) school here. He had a problem "coordinating his typin' fingers with his noggin"

name: Thomas L. Mckinney
ad_hist: University of London, Institute of Education,
description: Thomas L.Mckinney was an American corporal from Farmville, North Carolina, who attended the Institute of Education School here. The nickname of this former teacher was "the thin man".

name: E. Ita Ekpenyon
description: E. Ita Ekpenyon was a Nigerian air-raid warden in wartime Westminster who resided at this location. He served his community heroically during the worst of the Blitz.

name: Israel Oludotun Ransome-Kuti
description: Israel Oludotun Ransome-Kuti was a Nigerian clergyman and activist who came here in summer 1943 to "discuss affairs at WASU".

name: Ladipo Solanke
description: Ladipo Solanke was a Nigerian student, lawyer and the co-founder of the West African Student's Union who came here in the summer of 1943 to appeal for a WASU-friendly Trustee to be appointed to the WASU hostel.

name: Robert Gardiner
description: Robert Gardiner was a Ghanaian economist who sat on the Anglo-African Committee of the Church Assembly Missionary Council.

name: Harold Moody
description: Harold Moody was a Jamaican doctor and founder of the LCP who was invited here to discuss "the Leagueâ€™s proposal to do something to help the Negro American troops".

name: Oladigbolu Coker
description: Oladigbolu Coker was the Nigerian Vice-President of WASU and Chairman of the Hotel board during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

name: John M. Coco-Bassey
description: J.M. Coco-Bassey was a Nigerian man who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

name: Olive Johnson
description: Olive Johnson was a Sierra Leonese woman who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

name: E.A.N.FF. Crabbe
description: E.A.N.FF. Crabbe was a West African barrister and President of WASU during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

name: L. Alli Balogun
description: L. Alli Balogun was a Nigerian student who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

name: W.A.G. Richter
description: W.A.G. Richter was a West African student from Edinburgh University who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

name: A. Curtis
description: A. Curtis was a West African woman who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

name: O.A. Thomas
description: O.A. Thomas was a Nigerian law student who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

description: O. Egbuna was a Nigerian man who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

description: F.O. Blaize was a wealthy Nigerian merchant and Honourable Secretary of WASU who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

description: Alhaj. I. A. Seriki was a Nigerian man who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

description: J. Galba Bankole Bright was a Sierra Leonese man who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

name: James Quist-Therson

name: R.W. Beoku-Betts
description: R.W. Beoku-Betts was a Sierra Leonese Director of Socials at WASU and future WASU President who was present during Clement Attlee's visit to the WASU Hostel in Spring 1942.

st_first: The Honourable Society of the Middle Temple
description: R.W. Beoku-Betts was a Sierra Leonese law student who trained to be a barrister here.

name: F.O. Blaize

description: F.O. Blaize was a wealthy Nigerian merchant and Honourable Secretary of WASU who trained to be a barrister here.

name: O. A. Thomas
st_first: The Honourable Society of the Middle Temple
description: O.A. Thomas was a Nigerian law student who trained to become a barrister here.

name: Frederick Rotimi Williams
description: Frederick Rotimi Williams was a Cambridge University law student and future President of the Nigerian Bar Association who was a member of WASU in 1941

name: M.E.R. Okorodudu
description: M.E.R. Okorodudu was a Nigerian student and future Chief who was a member of WASU in 1941.

name: Emmanuel Obetsebi-Lamptey
description: Emmanuel Obetsebi-Lamptey was a Ghanaian activist and one of the "Bix Six" who founded and led the United Gold Coast Convention (UGCC). He was a member of WASU in 1941.

name: Emmanuel Obetsebi-Lamptey
st_first: The Honourable Society of the Inner Temple
description: Emmanuel Obetsebi-Lamptey was a Ghanaian activist and one of the "Bix Six" who founded and led the United Gold Coast Convention (UGCC). He studied law at the Inner Temple.

name: A.J.Akinwumi
description: A.J.Akinwumi was a Nigerian law student who was a member of WASU in 1941.

name: F. Kakan-Boadu
description: F. Kakan-Boadu was a male member of WASU in 1941.

name: C. Kessie
description: C. Kessie was a long time Ghanaian member of WASU.

name: Ali Balogun
description: Ali Balogun was a Nigerian law student and member of WASU in 1941.

name: Ola Balogun
description: Olu Balogun was a Nigerian law student and member of WASU in 1941.

name: Charles Onyeama
description: Charles Dadi Onyeama  was a future Justice of the Supreme Court of Nigeria who was a member of WASU in 1941.

name: T.T Solaru
description: Reverend T.T Solaru was a future Nigerian Bishop who was a member of WASU in 1941.

name: A.J.Akinwumi
st_first: The Honourable Society of the Middle Temple

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was an American reporter for the Chicago Defender who thought his tube carriage had been hit by a German bomb when it stopped at Waterloo Station. In reality, it had been hit by the next train following behind. Thankfully no one was injured.

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was an American reporter for the Chicago Defender who visited the fish market here and observed with horror how the only cuts on offer were all offal.

name: February Jarrett
description: February Jarrett was a man bearing a striking resemblence to Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie who was arrested for loudly blowing a tin whistle near Piccadilly Square and tried here. Unable to pay his fine, February spent March 1943 in jail.

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was an American reporter for the Chicago Defender who visited Frisco's one Sunday in 1943 and talked to singer Fay Barton about her unusually long cigarette.

name: Fay Barton
description: Fay Barton was a Harlem singer who smoked an eight-inch long "Russian" cigarette at Frisco's club one Sunday in 1943.

name: Frisco (Bingham)
description: Frisco, whose official name was Bingham, was the American proprietor of Frisco's Club, which stood here until it was bombed and forced to relocate during the Second World War.

name: Frisco (Bingham)
description: Frisco, whose official name was Bingham, was the American proprietor of Frisco's Club, which was relocated here following being bombed in the early 1940s. The club would move again in 1949.

name: Ahnastasia Scott
description: Ahnastasia Scott was a American woman from Chicago who worked in the Liverpool branch of the Red Cross. She visited the Duchess during a trip to London, where she met David H. Orro, and asked him to call out her ex-husband in the Chicago Defender.

name: Leroy Credelle
description: Leroy Credelle was an Chicagoan who passed in and out of London, occasionally stopping at the Duchess club. David H. Orro described him as "rather peaked about th' puss."

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was an American reporter for the Chicago Defender who spotted another "son of the shade" whilst standing at the corner of Russel Square and Southampton row. He followed the man- Philip A. Behagen- and caught up to him at the next corner.

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was an American reporter for the Chicago Defender who spoke to "Long" Harry Parker, programme director at the Duchess Street Club, whilst the later was spending some time in the company of a blonde white woman.

name: Olive Blackwell
description: Olive Blackwell was a Chicagoan woman stationed with the American Red Cross in Northampton. She spoke to black journalist David H. Orro whilst waiting in a queue here waiting to see the film "Casablanca".

name: Philip A. Behagen
description: Philip A. Behagen was the Harlem-born Chief Steward of a merchant ship during the Second World War. In 1943 his ship docked in Northern England and he "immediately" travelled down to London via train. He was anxious to soak up the London atmosphere and meet local women.

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was an American reporter for the Chicago Defender who was a very frequent visitor to the Duchess Street Social Club, despite not being a GI himself (he was also frequently removed from the premises).

name: Julius Mason
description: Julius Mason was a Chicagoan quartermaster in the U.S. army who sat here drunk for ten minutes, dreaming of home. Eventually he was arrested by the police.

name: A. J. King
description: A.J. King was a Chicagoan native serving with the Canadaian armed forces who reminisced with David H. Orro about Chicago whilst the two hung out together at the Duchess Street Club.

name: "Long" Harry K. Parker
description: Harry Parker, nicknamed "Long Harry", was a former Livingston College American football coach who was programme director at the Duchess Club in Mayfair, and spoke to journalist David H. Orro here whilst in the company of a 'beautiful blonde woman'.

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was an American reporter for the Chicago Defender who watched a film here and spoke to Corporal O. V. Woods about his aunt in Chicago.

name: O. V. Woods
description: O. V. Woods was an American corporal who spoke to black journalist David H. Orro about his aunt in Chicago whilst watching a film here.

name: William "Woogie" Harris
description: William "Woogie" Harris was a piano player and singer who was present at the Lewis-Harvey fight here in 1936.

name: Helen Greenlee
description: Helen Greenlee was the wife of Gus Greenlee, who was present at the Lewis-Harvey fight here in 1936.

name: Gus Greenlee
description: Gus Greenlee was the manager of boxer John Henry Lewis who was present at the Lewis-Harvey fight here in 1936.

name: Paul Robeson
description: Paul Robeson was an American singer actor and socialist who was present at the Lewis-Harvey fight here in 1936.

name: Camille King Jones
description: Camille King Jones was a Chicagoan worker at the American Red Cross Liberty Club who was known as "London's Sweetheart" by black GIs.

name: Emperor Haile Selassie
description: Emperor Haile Selassie was the exiled Emperor of Ethiopia who stayed at this grand residence opposite Hyde Park after arriving in London in June 1936

name: Crown Prince Asfaw Wassen
description: Crown Prince Asfaw Wassen was the son of exiled Emperor of Ethiopia Haile Selassie who stayed at this grand residence opposite Hyde Park after arriving in London in June 1936

name: Princess Tsehai
description: Princess Tsehai was the daughter of exiled Emperor of Ethiopia Haile Selassie who stayed at this grand residence opposite Hyde Park after arriving in London in June 1936

name: Emperor Haile Selassie
description: Emperor Haile Selassie was the exiled Emperor of Ethiopia who visited this building, the Ethiopian Legation, upon his arrival in London in June 1936.

name: Una Marson
description: Una Marson was a Jamaican journalist and media producer who appeared here for a ceremony where Princes Tsahai was honoured in front of 2,500 spectators in an appearance sponsored by the Women's was Peace Crusade. Appearing as part of her role as the secretary of the Ethiopian Legation, Marson mistaken for the Princess and given a thunderous applause when she emerged.

name: Princess Tsehai
description: Princess Tsehai was the daughter of exiled Emperor of Ethiopia Haile Selassie who was feted in front of 2,500 here in 1936 as part of a ceremony organized by the Women's Peace Crusade.

name: Una Marson
description: Una Marson was a Jamaican journalist and media producer who appeared here to report for a New York newspaper. Marson described the servicemen in the club as quiet and subdued. "I know what they were thinking," she wrote, "they were back home with you."

name: P. Thorpee
description: P. Thorpee was the chief fire officer of Sierra Leone, who was pictured listening to some records on the radiogram in the lounge of the Colonial Club, Russell Square.

name: Mr N'jie
description: Mr N'jie was a Gambian law student pictured unpacking his bags in his Colonial Centre dormitory.
citation: Photograph (D 20012) from the collections of the Imperial War Museum

name: Alfred Stanismore
description: Alfred Stanismore was the Belizean reception clerk at the Colonial Centre.

name: Mr Colley
description: Mr Colley was a journalism student from Gambia pictured outside the Colonial Centre.

description: Mr Magzaka was a medical student from South Africa pictured outside the Colonial Centre.

name: Rosamund Harding
description: Rosamund Harding was a student teacher from Sierra Leone who was pictured playing pool at the Colonial Centre.

description: D A Thomas was a law student from Sierra Leone who was pictured playing pool at the Colonial Centre.

description: J. J. Blair was a Pilot Officer from Jamaica pictured signing in to the Colonial Centre at 17 Russell Square for the night.

name: Stanley Carter
description: Stanley Carter was a man pictured playing on the piano in the Colonial Centre as part of an event organized there by the LCP.

name: Frank Baldwin
description: Frank Baldwin was a cook from Belize pictured carving a roast in the Colonial Centre's kitchens.

name: Robert Broadhurst
description: Robert Broadhurst was a Liberian pan-African activist involved in the International African Service Bureau (IASB) in the late 1930s who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register, which recorded his occupation as Acting Vice Consul for the Republic of Liberia

name: Ivor Cummings
description: Ivor Cummings was the British son of a Sierra Leonese physician who was the warden of Aggrey House and lived there at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Oladipo O. Pearse
description: Oladipo O. Pearse was a law student studying in London who was recorded staying at Aggrey House at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Babatunde O. Alakija
description: Babatunde O. Alakija was a Nigerian law student who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register and went on to train as a pilot during the war.

name: E. Ita Ekpenyon
description: E. Ita Ekpenyon was a Nigerian air-raid warden in wartime Westminster who resided at this location at the time of the 1939 Register. He served his community heroically during the worst of the Blitz.

name: Oladigbolu Coker
description: Oladigbolu Coker was a leader in the West African Students Union (WASU) who was recorded living here at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: John M. Coco-Bassey
description: John M. Coco-Bassey was a Nigerian law student involved with the West African Students Union (WASU) who was recorded living here at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: O. Egbuna
description: O. Egbuna was a Nigerian law student involved with the West African Students Union (WASU) who was recorded living here at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: James Quist-Therson
description: James Quist-Therson was a law student who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register. He later became a barrister and was active in the West Indian Students Union (WASU) and attended a visit by Clement Atlee to its hostel in Camden in 1942.

name: Emmanuel Obetsebi-Lamptey
description: Emmanuel Obetsebi-Lamptey was a Ghanaian activist and one of the "Bix Six" who founded and led the United Gold Coast Convention (UGCC). He studied law at the Inner Temple.

name: Okai Robertson
description: Okai Robertson was a Ghanaian law student who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Koi Obuadabong Larbi
description: Koi Obuadabong Larbi was a Ghanaian law student who became chairman of the Committee for the Defence of People of African Descent who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: A. Babington Olumuyiwa
description: A. Babington Olumuyiwa was a Nigerian student who lived here with his wife Betty at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Emanuel Afolabi Fowler
description: Emanuel Afolabi Fowler was a tailor's apprentice who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Edenslight Ejesha Osora
description: Edenslight Ejesha Osora was a Nigerian reverend who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Vincent A. Savage
description: Vincent A. Savage was a law student who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: James F. D. Godonu
description: James F. D. Godonu was a Nigerian man who later joined the RAF who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register, which recorded his occupation at the outbreak of war as a 'stage and film artiste'.

name: Dorothy Purser
description: Dorothy Purser came from Jamaica to train here at Salvation Army's International Training College in 1941.

name: Dorothy Purser
description: Dorothy Pursuer came from Jamaica to work here at the Salvation Army's Mothers' Hospital in 1941 after being commissioned in the Salvation Army.

name: Amy Barbour-James
description: Amy Barbour-James was the daughter of Guianans John and Caroline, born in West Acton in 1906, who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Avril Coleridge-Taylor
description: Avril Coleridge-Taylor was the daughter of mixed-race composer Samuel Coleridge-Taylor who lived here with her sister Jaylen Ann at the time of the 1939 Register. Avril became a successful composer and conductor in her own right during the 1930s and after the war.

name: Jaylen Ann Coleridge-Taylor
description: Jaylen Ann Coleridge-Taylor was the daughter of mixed-race composer Samuel Coleridge-Taylor who lived here with her sister Avril at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: James Jackson Brown
description: James Jackson Brown was a Jamaican doctor who lived and practiced here for several decades.

name: Gerald Brown
description: Gerald Brown was the eldest son of Jamaican doctor James Jackson Brown who lived and practiced here for several decades.

name: Leslie Brown
description: Leslie Brown was the second son of Jamaican doctor James Jackson Brown who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register, which recorded his occupation as a motor engineer turner.

name: J. Acman Holland
description: J. Acman Holland was a Jamaican chiropractor and 'nerve specialist' who lived and worked here for a period in the late 1930s. Holland also practiced in New York City and Jamaica and wrote to a relative in 1938 that, 'As I am situated, I donâ€™t have to bother with coloured people at all, and not even poor white ones, as I am surrounded by the rich in one of the richest section [sic] in London'.

name: Josie Woods
description: Josie Woods was a British dancer who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register. Woods was born in 1912 in Canning Town, the daughter of a Dominican sailor, and her theatrical career included time in the 'Eight Black Streaks', reputedly the UK's first established black dance troupe.

name: John Caswell Smith
description: John Caswell Smith took over from Sidney Williams as director of the Duchess Club for African American service personnel in 1943. He was formerly the director of the Boston Urban League.

name: Edwina Carrie
description: Edwina Carrie, originally from Philadelphia, was John Caswell Smith's assistant, involved in the running of the Duchess Club for African American service personnel.

name: James A. Gregg
description: James A. Gregg was a bishop in the AME church who visited black GIs at the Liberty Club for African American service personnel in 1944.

name: Pvt. Homer Ranson
description: Pvt. Homer Ranson was stationed in the UK in 1944 and socialized at the Liberty Club for African American service personnel.

name: Pvt. Charles Bellard
description: Pvt. Charles Bellard was stationed in the UK in 1944 and socialized at the Liberty Club for African American service personnel.

name: Maida Springer
description: Maida Springer was a trade unionist who represented the American Federation of Labor on a goodwill tour of the UK in 1945, during which time she visited the Liberty Club for African American service personnel.

name: Skip Hall
description: Skip Hall was stationed in the UK in 1945 and socialized at the Liberty Club for African American service personnel.

name: Reginald Connoly
description: Reginald Connoly was stationed in the UK in 1945 and socialized at the Liberty Club for African American service personnel.

name: Leonard Hill
description: Leonard Hill was involved in the running of the Liberty Club for African American service personnel in 1944.

description: Daisy Carry was involved in the running of the Liberty Club for African American service personnel in 1944.

name: Milton Larry
description: Milton Larry, orginally from Washington, became director of the Libery Club for African American service personnel in 1945

name: Julia Johnson
description: Julia Johnson, originally from Indianapolis, was involved in the running of the Liberty Club for African American service personnel in 1945.

name: Viola Murphy
description: Viola Murphy, orginally from Harrisburg Pa., was involved in the running of the Liberty Club for African American service personnel in 1945.

name: Esther Cooper
description: Esther Cooper was an American activist who spoke on behalf of the Southern Negro Youth Congress at a 'World Federation Democratic Youth' conference here in November 1945.

name: Jonathan Hyde
description: Jonathan Hyde was part of the Sierra Leoneon delegation to the 'World Federation Democratic Youth' conference here in November 1945.

name: G. Kio Amachree
description: G. Kio Amachree was part of the Nigerian delegation to the 'World Federation Democratic Youth' conference here in November 1945.

name: Evan Ayo Rosiji
description: Evan Ayo Rosiji was part of the Nigerian delegation to the 'World Federation Democratic Youth' conference here in November 1945.

name: Elizabeth Phillips
ad_hist: American Red Cross Officer's Club for Women
description: Elizabeth Phillips was the first African American women to be sent to report on the war. She reported the American Red Cross Officer's Club for Women on Charles Street 'maintains jim-crow living quarters', which constituted 'the only instance of jim-crow I found during my short stay in London'.

name: Vincent Tubbs
description: Vincent Tubbs was an African American war correspondent who passed through Victoria Station on his way to the front in France. His report detailed how he was carrying 'two handbags, gas mask, duffel bag, typewriter, briefcase and self'.

name: Jack Hamilton
description: Jack Hamilton was an African American musician who formerly played with Louis Armstrong, who in 1942, set up the Cafe Society club in Soho. Hamilton had formerly played at the Embassy and Jig's clubs which were nearby.

name: Walter J. Forester
description: Walter J. Forester was a Senior Sergeant in the US Army who visited here on a tour of several of the city's tourist destinations.
