name: James L. Rogers
description: James L. Rogers, originally from Washington State, ran the Liberty Club for African American service personnel toward the end of the war.

name: Marie Wilburn
description: Marie Wilburn, originally from St. Louis, was involved in the running of the Liberty Club for African American service personnel toward the end of the war.

name: Lois Laster
description: Lois Laster, originally from Canton, Ohio, was involved in the running of the Liberty Club for African American service personnel toward the end of the war.

name: Chick Alexander
description: Chick Alexander, originally from Jamaica, was an actor who was involved in the arts and theatre scene in London. He performed in George Black's "Get a Load of This" at the London Hippodrome in 1942.

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was an African American journalist for the Chicago Defender who visited the Bow Street Magistrate Court to attend the trial of an American servicemember.

name: Camille King Jones
description: Camille King Jones was a Chicagoan worker at an American Red Cross club in Bristol at this time, she is introduced to David H. Orro whilst visiting the Duchess Club in London.

name: Lucyle McAlister
description: Lucyle McAlister was a Nebraskan who served as the Assistant Director of Operations at the Duchess Club in London after joining the American Red Cross. Prior to this, she had been the Director of Negro Work for the USO.

name: Margaret Simms
description: Margaret Simms was an American singer from Florida who joined the American Red Cross during the war. She performed at the Rainbow Corner Red Cross Club in London as the starting point of her tour through England.

name: I.T.A. Wallace-Johnson
description: I. T. A. Wallace-Johnson was a Sierra Leoneon activist who led a meeting here i 1937 where it was reportedly decided to form the International African Service Bureau. A report by the Metropolitan Police's Special Branch, tasked with monitoring subversive political groups, noted its purpose would be to 'collect information from contacts in the colonies and dominions, especially that related to coloured peoples' and publish this in a bulletin.

name: Henrine Ward
description: Henrine Ward was one of the staff members at the Rainbow Corner Red Cross Club to greet the English Air Minister Sir Stafford Cripps and his wife when they visited the club. She also was in attendance when Eleanor Roosevelt visited sometime later.

name: Carol Jarrett
description: Carol Jarret was one of the American Red Cross staff members that greeted English Air Minister Sir Stafford Cripps and his wife when they visited the Rainbow Corner Red Cross Club. She also welcomed Eleanor Roosevelt when she visited there sometime later.

name: Avela Gabre
description: Professor Avela Gabre was the Ethiopian minister to the Court of St. James, and sat for an interview with Trinidadian activist George Padmore to discuss the foreign policy of Ethiopia.

name: George Padmore
description: Trinidadian activist George Padmore conducted an interview with the new Ethiopian minister Avela Gabre, discussing the future of the country as well as its foreign policy.

name: Maida Springer
description: Maida Springer was a trade unionist who represented the American Federation of Labor on a goodwill tour of the UK in 1945, during which time she visited Buckingham Palace.

name: Elizabeth McDougald
description: Elizabeth McDougald was a Red Cross worker in London that attended this hair salon alongside other Red Cross staff members.

name: Lavine Birch
description: Lavine Birch was a Bostonian who helped to run the Duchess Club in Mayfair. While in London, she visited a hair salon alongside other Red Cross staff members.

name: Ahnastasia Scott
description: Ahnastasia Scott was an American woman from Chicago who worked in the Liverpool Red Cross Club. While in London, she visited a hair salon alongside oother Red Cross staff members.

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was a wartime correspondent for the Chicago Defender based in London. One night during the Blitz, Orro took shelter in this station and interviewed some of the others located there.

name: Theodore Salavar
description: Theodore Salavar was a Trinidadian who was living in London during the Blitz. He sheltered in the Russell Square Tube Station one night and was interviewed by David H. Orro.

name: David H. Orro
description: David H. Orro was a wartime correspondent for the Chicago Defender based in London. Orro took shelter in this tube station during a Luftwaaffe air-raid in early March, 1943.

name: Eric Williams
description: Eric Williams was a Trinidadian student, historian and future Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago who lived here during his time in London.

name: Elsie Williams (nee Ribeiro)
description: Elsie Williams was a Trinidadian who married Eric Williams, future Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago, in Hampstead in the 1930s and lived with him here before they left for the United States.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who lived here briefly.

name: George Padmore
description: George Padmore was a Trinidadian activist who stayed briefly with Jomo Kenyatta here.

name: Jomo Kenyatta
description: Jomo Kenyatta was a Kenyan student and activist and the future president of an independent Kenya who lived at a flat on this road during his time in London.

name: Babalola Wilkie
description: Babalola Wilkie was a Nigerian involved in WASU who also owned a popular club here on Greek Street.

name: Laurie Deniz
description: Laurie Deniz, originally from Cardiff, was among the black musicians to play at Babalola Wilkie's club on Greek Street.

name: Joseph Cozier
description: Joseph Cozier, originally from British Guiana, lived his with his family at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Eugene Cozier
description: Eugene Cozier, the son of Joseph Cozier from British Guiana, was six years old when he lived here with his family at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Henry Cozier
description: Henry Cozier, the son of Joseph Cozier from British Guiana, was four years old when he lived here with his family at the time of the 1939 Register.

name: Charity Adams Earley
description: Charity Adams Earley was the African American CO of the famous 6888th Central Postal District Battalion of African American personnel, and she reported to this headquarters of the Women's Army Auxiliary Core on her arrival in the city in early 1945.
